title: Where does 'You're the reason we can't have nice things' come from? - Quora

response.answer_text: Kids are like wrecking balls and that's still an understatement I think, of course, most of us might not like to think of our children in terms of the things they have destroyed, but over the years it becomes apparent that no matter how beautiful you might think a white carpet is, no matter how plush and silky it might feel… the reality of having those things when there are small children in the house, means you get good at snipping rugs, that start off plushy and end up sticky and matted, often with substances unknown. And it isn't their fault that they can't eat ice cream without getting covered in the stuff, but these things happen and you get used to it, as a parent. I spent a small fortune once on a digital washing machine and the circuit board burnt out, perhaps because of little fingers switching the dial, I can't know for sure but I didn't pay more the next one, I stook with the cheaper washing machine just because i accepted that accidents are more likely to happen when the children are small. Its not a sentence that I would probably ever speak out loud, because it's accusing and is the same as saying “you are a house wrecker”… and most parents value their kids happiness over domestic status symbols, any day of the week. But at the same time it is definitely true that some people continue into adulthood with the same lack of awareness that leaves light switches dirty from dirty hands and smudges on walls, and stains on tables that simply wouldn't be there “but for.. “ a messy person… Haha, I might be writing this like some organised immaculate person, but I am terrible also, especially when I'm busy doing things I enjoy, like painting or gardening, then the house can get easily messed up and untidy and that makes it impossible to chill out and relax in, for other people. So the origin of the saying probably comes from someone who is used to having to tidy up and clean a lot because they live with someone who doesn't. And if they are saying “you” it means “you are messy or cause damage to stuff around you and that affects them, including their “will” to invest in anything “expensive” because based on their past experiences, enjoying new products doesn't last long. I wouldn't let it offend you though, it's more of a prompt to encourage you to be more mindful than you have been “in the past” so you can learn to be more appreciative of things that maybe you've not realised by yourself… or maybe they are just blaming you for stuff that wasn't well made and would of fallen to pieces If a mouse had tried leaning on it.

I first heard it from Adam Savage on Mythbusters, after they had destroyed yet another car, but I think he was quoting from some unknown source. This from Stackexchange: What is the origin of the phrase "This is why we can't have nice things"?
It comes from having kids. Lol.
